content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions regarding subsidy fees. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to adjust subsidy fees, with the maximum amount not exceeding 1.38 percent per year, and the deadline extended to September 30, 2001. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to adjust subsidy fees, with a maximum amount of 1.38 percent per year, and the deadline extended to September 30, 2001. The amendments become effective on October 1, 2001. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. Amends Section 312 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 by removing a specific disclosure requirement. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. (a) Criminal Penalties.--Section 1014 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include small business investment companies as defined in the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 or the Small Business Administration. (b) Civil Penalties.--Section 951 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is amended to renumber subsections and make changes to subsection (c). In subsection (c), amendments are made to include section 16(a) of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 645(a)) and specify the effective date of the section. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amends Section 313 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to address the removal or suspension of management officials. SEC. 313 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines 'management official' as an individual involved in the management of a licensee. The Administrator can issue a written notice of intention to remove a management official for willful violations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines a 'management official' as an individual involved in licensee management. The Administrator can issue a notice to remove a management official for willful violations under this Act, any related regulations, or a final cease-and-desist order. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for the removal of a management official who has willfully breached fiduciary duties involving personal dishonesty. The notice must state the grounds for removal and schedule a hearing. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for the removal of a management official for breaching fiduciary duties. If the management official does not appear at the hearing, they will be deemed to have consented to the issuance of an order of removal. If consent is given or if the Administrator finds grounds for removal, an order of removal will be issued. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office if grounds specified in the notice have been established, becoming effective after 30 days of service upon the licensee and management official concerned. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office, effective after 30 days of service, and remain enforceable unless modified or set aside by the Administrator or a reviewing court. Management officials may seek judicial review in the district where the licensee is located or in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for a stay of the suspension pending administrative proceedings. The court has jurisdiction to stay such action. Management officials can also be suspended on criminal charges involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit management officials from participating in licensee affairs for protection in cases involving felonies of dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension or prohibition remains effective until the legal matter is resolved or terminated by the Administrator. The Administrator has the authority to remove a management official upon conviction for offenses described in paragraph (1), with the removal becoming effective upon service of the order to the licensee. A finding of not guilty or other disposition of charges does not preclude the Administrator from instituting proceedings to suspend or remove the management official from office. Notification to Licensees: Notices served on a management official must also be served on the interested licensee. Hearing venues are determined based on the location of the licensee's principal office and conducted in accordance with chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. After a hearing, the Administrator will render a decision within 90 days and issue orders consistent with the provisions of this section. The Administrator also has the authority to modify orders. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time, with proper notice and in the manner deemed appropriate. Judicial review is available through a petition filed in a court of appeals of the United States. Judicial review of orders issued under this section can be obtained by filing a petition in the court of appeals of the United States within 30 days. The petition can request modification, termination, or setting aside of the Administrator's order. A copy of the petition must be sent to the Administrator for review. Upon filing a petition in the court of appeals within 30 days, the court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the Administrator's order. Review of the proceedings will be conducted accordingly. Judicial review of the Administrator's order is conducted in the court of appeals within 30 days. The review process follows the procedures outlined in chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code. The court's judgment is final but can be reviewed by the Supreme Court upon certiorari. Proceedings for judicial review do not automatically stay the order unless ordered by the court. Proceedings for judicial review do not automatically stay any order issued by the Administrator under this section, unless specifically ordered by the court. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Guarantee fees under Section 7(a)(18) of the Small Business Act will be reduced for loans approved during a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002. The guarantee fee will be 1 percent for loans up to $150,000 and 2.5 percent for loans above that amount. During a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, guarantee fees for Section 7(a) loans will be reduced. The fee will be 1 percent for loans up to $150,000, 2.5 percent for loans between $150,000 and $700,000, and 3.5 percent for loans over $700,000. Additionally, annual fees will be assessed for loans approved during this period. During the 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, annual fees will be assessed for loans approved, with the fee amounting to 0.25 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. Additionally, Section 504 fees will be reduced as per the amendments made to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. During the 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, the Administration may not assess or collect any up front guarantee fee for loans made. During the 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, the Small Business Administration may not assess or collect any up front guarantee fee for loans made under this title. Loans and financings approved during this period will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. The amendments made by this section to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2002, and funds must be made available under appropriations Acts to offset the cost of the amendments.
